importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article reports on a policy change by Walmart on October 21, 2025, following President Trump's announcement of a new H-1B visa fee.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy shift at Walmart and the new H-1B fee are part of the current political and economic landscape in the U.S. related to immigration and labor policy in 2025.

keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign candidates requiring H-1B visas after President Donald Trump raised the H-1B visa fee to $100,000.
The H-1B visa is a work visa valid for three years and renewable for another three years, used primarily by U.S. companies to hire skilled foreign workers.
Major tech companies are the largest users of the H-1B program, while Walmart employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders.
The new visa fee is intended by the Trump administration to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program.
The policy change disproportionately affects skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of approved H-1B applications.
Economists argue that the H-1B program supports U.S. business competitiveness and job creation.
Walmart’s spokesperson emphasized the company’s commitment to hiring top talent while being mindful of H-1B hiring practices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., has paused job offers to foreign workers needing H-1B visas following President Donald Trump's announcement of a $100,000 fee on the visa program designed for high-skilled professionals. This policy shift, reported by Bloomberg and covered by CNN, reflects growing tensions between immigration policy and business needs, particularly affecting skilled workers from India who dominate H-1B applications. While the Trump administration argues the fee targets abuse of the program, economists and companies like Walmart warn of significant disruptions to U.S. competitiveness and innovation, especially in tech and online retail sectors.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
